title: Why are GP visits getting so expensive?
description: If you recently received an email or text from your GP clinic saying they can no longer bulk bill – you’re not alone. Increasingly, GPs in Australia say the amount they are reimbursed by the government isn’t enough to cover expenses, and they have no option but to pass costs on to patients.Medical editor Melissa Davey explores why GP appointment costs are rising and how the Labor government plans to overhaul this system
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, reported by Melissa Davey, and produced by Allison Chan and Jane Lee. Sound design and mixing by Daniel Semo. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Why don’t women have as much super as men?
description: When women have children, separate from their partners or care for their loved ones later in life, their retirement savings take a hit. Reporter Stephanie Wood talks to Jane Lee about how compulsory superannuation is still failing women, 30 years after it was introduced in Australia
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee, produced by Karishma Luthria, Allison Chan, Joe Koning who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The Australian boy lost in a Syrian ‘black hole’ prison
description: There is a prison in Syria holding hundreds of children who have never been convicted of any crime. Michael Safi tells the story of one of them
contributors: Presented by Michael Safi; produced and executive produced by Joshua Kelly and Sami Kent; sound design by Rudi Zygadlo; executive producers Phil Maynard, Nicole Jackson and Elizabeth Cassin

title: The fallout from Scott Morrison’s secrecy – with Lenore Taylor
description: During his prime ministership, Scott Morrison secretly took on the health, finance, treasury, home affairs and resources portfolios. Facing the public in a press conference on Wednesday, Morrison insisted he did nothing wrong: it was an extraordinary time, which required extraordinary measures.In this episode of Full Story, Gabrielle Jackson talks to Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher about why Morrison’s reasoning doesn’t stack up, and how we prevent such a break with Westminster conventions from happening again
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher . Produced by Miles Herbert and Daniel Semo . Executive produced by Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: The hidden reason it’s so hard to get an abortion in Australia
description: Unlike most other medical procedures, abortion services come with an unusual caveat: doctors can refuse to provide them on religious or moral grounds. According to reproductive healthcare advocates, this is compounding longstanding access issues, with at least five women in one metropolitan area of Queensland having to continue unwanted pregnancies in recent months.Reporter Sophie Black explores how a doctor’s right to refuse abortion on religious or moral grounds is weighed against a woman’s right to healthcare in Australia.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Sophie Black. Produced by Karishma Luthria and Camilla Hannan, who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle JacksonMolly Glassey

title: Scott Morrison’s secret portfolios
description: After revelations that former prime minister Scott Morrison was secretly appointed to five additional ministerial portfolios during his term, the prime minister, Anthony Albanese, is seeking legal advice and promising to hold Morrison to account.Guardian Australia’s chief political correspondent Sarah Martin talks to Laura Murphy-Oates about how and why Morrison was appointed to these portfolios, and what this tells us about accountability and secrecy at the highest levels of government
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Sarah Martin. Produced by Joe Koning, with sound design and mixing by Daniel Semo. Executive Producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey, and Laura Murphy-Oates.

title: Tinder turns 10: what have we learned from a decade of dating apps?
description: Dating apps have opened up opportunities to meet more people, but what have they done to our psyche? Emily Witt looks at how they have shifted the way we understand modern love, sex and relationships
contributors: Presented by Nosheen Iqbal with Emily Witt. Produced by Ned Carter Miles, sound design by Rudi Zygadlo. Executive producers are Nicole Jackson, Joshua Kelly and Sami Kent.

title: One man reflects on a year since fleeing Afghanistan
description: It’s been a year since Afghanistan fell to the Taliban, when millions of Afghans tried desperately to flee the country in fear. One man who made it out on the last flight shares his story of evacuation and what his life in Australia has been like since then
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Noor Ramazan. Produced by Karishma Luthria  and Jane Lee. The Executive Producers areMiles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Molly Glassey

title: Serena Williams’s familiar and unfair choice – with Lenore Taylor
description: Serena Williams – one of the greatest athletes of all time – announced her retirement from tennis this week. Her choice between her career, and the physical labour of having a family, is not unfamiliar to many women around the world. Australia has one of the least generous parental leave programs in the developed world, forcing women to bear the brunt of caregiving responsibilities, and further entrenching an already stark gender pay gap. In this episode of Full Story, Gabrielle Jackson talks to Lenore Taylor and Jo Tovey about rethinking work, family, and what success looks like
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Josephine Tovey . Produced by Miles Herbert and Daniel Semo . Executive produced by Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Why was an Australian security firm collecting intelligence on asylum seekers?
description: Guardian Australia has revealed that the Australian government used a private security firm to collect intelligence on asylum seekers being held on Nauru, in 2016. Leaked documents show that asylum seekers who had contact with Australian journalists, lawyers and advocates were closely watched by intelligence officers.Reporter Christopher Knaus explains how this came about and talks to the people who were the subject of ‘intelligence reports’
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Christopher Knaus. Produced by Joe Koning, who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive Producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey, and Laura Murphy-Oates.

title: As more space junk falls to Earth, should we be worried?
description: Last week, debris from a suspected Chinese booster rocket made an uncontrolled return to Earth, reportedly falling just metres from villages in Malaysia and Indonesia, and triggering a rebuke from Nasa. This follows the recent discovery of SpaceX debris on a sheep farm in regional NSW.Jane Lee speaks to ANU astrophysicist Dr Brad Tucker and reporter Natasha May about why more space junk is falling to Earth, what risks it poses to our safety
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee, Produced by Karishma Luthria, Joey Watson and Jane Lee. Sound design and mixing by Daniel Semo Executive Producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey, Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The rehabilitation of Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman
description: Middle East correspondent Martin Chulov discusses how the crown prince of Saudi Arabia has been re-embraced on the world stage, four years after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi
contributors: presented by Michael Safi with Martin Chulov; produced by Natalie Ktena and Rudi Zygadlo; executive producers Sami Kent, Phil Maynard and Elizabeth Cassin

title: Labor’s climate bill and the power of the Australian Greens
description: Labor’s climate bill, enshrining their emissions reduction targets into law, is set to pass both Houses of Parliament. The support of the Greens party - which now holds considerable power in the Senate - was hard won but Greens leader Adam Bandt warns “the fight to stop Labor opening new coal and gas mines continues”.Environment editor Adam Morton explores what this moment means for climate action in Australia and how the Greens party could shape climate politics in the 47th parliament
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, reported by Adam Morton. Produced by Karishma Luthria, Joey Watson, and Camilla Hannan who also did the sound design. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glassey and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Is an Indigenous voice to parliament achievable?
description: Last week, during a historic speech at the Garma festival, Anthony Albanese made a promise to push forward with a referendum, asking Australians a simple question: Do you support a constitutionally enshrined Indigenous voice to parliament? In this episode of Full Story, Gabrielle Jackson talks to Lenore Taylor and Lorena Allam about the long road to recognition
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Lorena Allam . Produced by Miles Herbert and Daniel Semo . Executive produced by Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Can Labor fix Australia’s economy?
description: With another official interest rate rise announced this week - marking the biggest increase since 1994 - the government and the reserve bank are issuing a warning: Australia’s economic woes are far from over. Economics correspondent Peter Hannam explores how long these tough conditions are expected to last, and whether Labor has a plan to ease the pressure on households
contributors: Reported by Peter Hannam and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates; produced by Jane Leeand Joe Koning who also did the sound design and mixing; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glasseyand Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Royals, records and a pop star at the Commonwealth Games
description: Australia is leading the medal tally at the 22nd Commonwealth Games, with swimmer Emma McKeon becoming the most successful athlete in the Games’ history. All while the swimming team is at the centre of a media frenzy involving the personal life of pop star turned professional swimmer, Cody Simpson.Guardian Australia’s deputy sport editor Emma Kemp explores the highs and lows of the event so far, and whether the Games paper over Britain’s colonial history
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, reported by Emma Kemp. Produced by Joe Koning and Karishma Luthria. Sound design and mixing by Daniel Semo. Executive producers Miles Martignoni, Molly Glassey and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Is Australia’s health system racist?
description: Reporter Joe Hinchliffe and Jane Lee unpack questions about race and cultural bias in the deaths of three children under hospital supervision, and haematologist Associate Prof Nada Hamad explains how racism impacts healthcare in Australia
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee and reported by Joe Hinchliffe. Produced by Karishma Luthria, Jane Lee and Daniel Semo who also did the sound design and mixing. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson  and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Do the Democrats have a Biden problem?
description: The approval ratings of the US president are at a record low. Washington DC bureau chief David Smith considers whether Joe Biden will stand for re-election in 2024
contributors: Presented by Michael Safi with David Smith; produced by Ned Carter Miles and Eva Krysiak; sound design by Axel Kacoutié; executive producers Joshua Kelly and Phil Maynard

title: Why is Jacinda Ardern more popular overseas than in New Zealand?
description: In 2017, Jacindamania swept the world. A young, charismatic New Zealander led the Labour party to victory. But lately, Ardern and the New Zealand Labour government have slumped in the polls. In this episode of Full Story, Gabrielle Jackson talks to Mike Ticher and Bonnie Malkin about the challenges facing New Zealand’s government and Ardern’s enduring appeal abroad
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Bonnie Malkin and Mike Ticher . Produced by Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan . Executive produced by Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: How good neighbours became good friends
description: After 37 years, Australia’s longest running drama, Neighbours, has come to an end. Along the way, the TV soap launched the careers of the likes of Kylie Minogue, Margot Robbie and Guy Pearce and has taken many zany plot twists – including numerous untimely deaths, one disappearance at sea and a few secret families. But for much of its history, the show didn’t reflect the diverse population of Australia, and has also recently faced allegations of racism on set.Writer Anna Spargo-Ryan explores why audiences kept coming back for more, and the complex legacy of Neighbours
contributors: Featuring Anna Spargo-Ryan and Laura Murphy-Oates; produced by Joe Koningwho also did the sound design; the executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson, Molly Glasseyand Laura Murphy-Oates
